awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Single Crystal Diffractometer for Teaching and Research at Rutgers University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Rutgers University-New Brunswick is acquiring a single crystal X-ray diffractometer (SCXRD) to support Professor Alan Goldman and colleagues Edward Arnold, Jing Li, Weiwei Xie and Jianyuan Zhang. In general, an X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles, and provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. The studies described here impact many areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry, and biochemistry. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate and graduate students as well as collaborators from other regional institutions such as Princeton University, City University of New York and the University of Delaware. 

The award of this diffractometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts the development of transition-metal-based catalysts for transformations of simple organic molecules and the characterization of crystalline solid-state inorganic and inorganic-organic hybrid materials. The instrumentation is also used for determining the structures of non-centrosymmetric superconductors and interplay of topology and magnetism in quantum materials and studying molecular mechanisms of HIV polyprotein precursors and reverse transcriptase. The instrument also serves researchers investigating endohedral metal cluster control in metallofullerene derivatives for use as molecular qubits and those designing molecular organometallic catalysts and supramolecular structures for energy-related transformations and functional materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
An X-ray diffractometer was acquired with support from this NSF award. X-ray diffractometry allows extremely precise determination of the structure of molecules and other materials at the atomic level, which is invaluable in understanding such materials. The instrument has significantly advanced research efforts at Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey and at partnering institutions.

The Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology at Rutgers-New Brunswick, the home department of the PIs, has made the most extensive use of the diffractometer. However, its impact extends well beyond, benefiting research in the Rutgers-New Brunswick Departments of Physics, Geology, Food Science, Marine Science, and Anthropology, and even the Mason Gross School of the Arts. The instrument has also been used by faculty and students at Rutgers-Camden, Stevens Institute of Technology, SUNY Stony Brook, Montclair State University, and Monmouth University. Industry scientists from Colgate-Palmolive and PTC Therapeutics have likewise leveraged the instrument for their R&D work.

To date, the instrument acquired with support from this award has enabled nearly 1,000 single-crystal structure determinations and over 700 powder diffraction studies. These data have supported numerous publications, grant applications, and collaborative projects across academia and industry.

For example:

The group of PI Alan Goldman has determined nearly 300 molecular single-crystal structures, contributing to the development of improved catalysts for more efficient transformations of hydrocarbons (e.g. for synthetic fuel production), and innovative methods for the conversion of nitrogen (from air) into ammonia for use as fertilizer and fuel.

The laboratory of Prof. Kate Waldie has used the instrument to determine over 100 single-crystal structures of transition metal complexes, which has supported the discovery of new catalysts for the development of fuel cells, and the development of novel fluorination methods for pharmaceutical and fine chemical synthesis. 

Prof. Mark Lipke's research group has utilized the diffractometer extensively for analyzing molecular building blocks that the group uses for constructing functional materials. This affords an understanding of how the pore sizes of molecular cages, or electronic delocalization in redox-active metal complexes, correlate with the bulk properties, such as catalytic activity or conductivity, of materials assembled from these components. 

The research group of co-PI Prof. Jianyuan Zhang has used the diffractometer to characterize metallofullerene derivatives of miniscule quantities with significant disorder. Due to the extremely challenging nature of this task, similar work is often done at synchrotron facilities worldwide. With the new diffractometer, however, they have successfully obtained key results to support the discovery of several new reactions for these molecules.

Prof. Charles Dismukes' research group has made extensive use of the new instrument to characterize catalysts and interfaces for the development of improved solar energy systems, based on materials including transition metal oxides, nitrides, phosphides and arsenides, as well as crystalline thin layer deposits on photovoltaic interfaces.

The Pulsed Laser for Spatiotemporal and Synthesis Experimentation (PuLSSE) Group at Rutgers University-Camden utilized the instrument to determine the structure and composition of bismuth-based nanomaterials, which are increasingly recognized for their promising electronic and optical properties, particularly in electrochemical and biomedical applications. 

The laboratory of Prof. Teddy Asefa has used the instrument to characterize several nanostructured electrocatalysts and photocatalysts for energy applications including water splitting, CO2 hydrogenation, and metal-air batteries.

Prof. Vitaly Podzorov's research group has used the diffractometer to determine the exact crystal structure and orientation of epitaxial single crystalline films of cesium lead bromide perovskite for their use in novel perovskite transistors.

The laboratory of Prof. Paul Takhistov has utilized the instrument to characterize the crystalline structure and phase composition of nanoscale micronutrients. It was also used to characterize fabricated pharmaceutical nanoparticles, enabling precise assessment of solid-state properties critical for bioavailability and stability properties.

In the research group of Prof. Jak Chakhalian, the diffractometer allowed characterization of thin films of novel perovskites, a critically important step toward the creation of state-of-the-art quantum materials.
